results.title: For the Love of Beer and His Buddies
results.abstract: “The Greatest Beer Run Ever” tells the story of Chickie Donohue’s unlikely but true adventure bringing suds from New York to his military pals in 1967 Vietnam.

multimedia.caption: Chickie Donohue at the Tubby Hook Tavern in Inwood, Manhattan. He says of his trek to Vietnam: “Obviously I never dreamed it’d be a movie.”
multimedia.copyright: George Etheredge for The New York Times

results.title: The Not-So-Silent Friendship of Jason Mewes and Kevin Smith
results.abstract: The two, who have played the characters Jay and Silent Bob for 28 years and counting, reflect on their time as best friends and professional partners.

results.title: Film Academy’s Museum Connects With Visitors in First Year
results.abstract: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures attracted about 20 percent more people than it expected since opening in September 2021. Now it needs to keep the momentum going.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Costumes on display at the Academy Museum, including one at right worn by Taron Egerton in “Rocketman.” The museum says it attracted more than 700,000 visitors in its first year.
multimedia.copyright: Rozette Rago for The New York Times

results.title: Why Does Hollywood Keep Using Fat Suits?
results.abstract: The industry’s unforgiving standards are well known. Can it pivot to include a range of sizes and body types?

results.title: Women and Gen Z Drive ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ Box Office
results.abstract: Harry Styles powered the critically drubbed and controversy-entangled movie to a solid $19.2 million in estimated ticket sales at North American cinemas.

multimedia.caption: Harry Styles and Florence Pugh in “Don’t Worry Darling,” directed by Olivia Wilde.

results.title: Elizabeth Banks Thinks This Interview Is Dangerous for Her
results.abstract: “The studio head is going to read it and be like, ‘Wow, that Liz Banks has got a lot to say.’ ”

results.title: Lena Dunham Channels a Voice of a (Different) Generation
results.abstract: With “Catherine Called Birdy,” she tackles a beloved Y.A. novel set in medieval England. It’s a project she had dreamed of since the start of “Girls.”

multimedia.caption: Lena Dunham views “Catherine Called Birdy” as part of a trilogy with her films “Tiny Furniture” and “Sharp Stick”: All are about a young woman coming-of-age.
multimedia.copyright: OK McCausland for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ Review: Burning Down the Dollhouse
results.abstract: Florence Pugh plays a seemingly happy housewife whose world starts to crack apart in Olivia Wilde’s wobbly feminist gothic.

multimedia.caption: Florence Pugh and Harry Styles in Olivia Wilde’s “Don’t Worry Darling.”

results.title: ‘Athena’ Review: Oh Brothers, Where Art Thou?
results.abstract: A besieged French housing project is the setting for Romain Gavras’s relentlessly kinetic action movie.

multimedia.caption: Dali Benssalah, left, and Sami Slimane in “Athena,” from the director Romain Gavras.
Dali Benssalah, left, and Sami Slimane in “Athena,” from the director Romain Gavras.

results.title: ‘Mona Lisa and the Blood Moon’ Review: Escape From New Orleans
results.abstract: This hyper-stylized quasi-superhero movie by Ana Lily Amirpour follows a mental hospital patient with supernatural abilities; it looks a lot more fun than it actually is.
des_facet: Mona Lisa and the Blood Moon (Movie)

multimedia.caption: From left, Jong-seo Jun, Evan Whitten and Ed Skrein in “Mona Lisa and the Blood Moon.”
From left, Jong-seo Jun, Evan Whitten and Ed Skrein in “Mona Lisa and the Blood Moon.”
From left, Jong-seo Jun, Evan Whitten and Ed Skrein in “Mona Lisa and the Blood Moon.”

results.title: ‘What We Leave Behind’ Review: A Father’s Final Project
results.abstract: At 89, Julián Moreno began building a home in Mexico for his children who had immigrated to the U.S. His granddaughter made the poignant documentary “What We Leave Behind.”

multimedia.caption: Julián Moreno in the documentary “What We Leave Behind.”
Julián Moreno in the documentary “What We Leave Behind.”
Julián Moreno in the documentary “What We Leave Behind.”

results.title: ‘I Didn’t See You There’ Review: A View From His Seat
results.abstract: The filmmaker Reid Davenport, by turns pensive and irritated, takes viewers inside his life as a disabled person through footage shot entirely from his perspective.

multimedia.caption: A scene from the personal essay film “I Didn’t See You There,” directed by Reid Davenport.
A scene from the personal essay film “I Didn’t See You There,” directed by Reid Davenport.
A scene from the personal essay film “I Didn’t See You There,” directed by Reid Davenport.

results.title: ‘InHospitable’ Review: Fight for Survival
results.abstract: Patients push back on a medical behemoth in this persuasive health care documentary.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “InHospitable,” a film directed by Sandra Alvarez.
A scene from “InHospitable,” a film directed by Sandra Alvarez.
A scene from “InHospitable,” a film directed by Sandra Alvarez.

results.title: ‘Sirens’ Review: The Risk in Rocking Out in Beirut
results.abstract: A documentary about an all-female metal group in Lebanon shows the difficulties of asserting complex identities in a repressive environment.

multimedia.caption: In “Sirens,” Lilas Mayassi and Shery Bechara, the founders of the Lebanese thrash metal band Slave to Sirens, have a rough road ahead of them.
In “Sirens,” Lilas Mayassi and Shery Bechara, the founders of the Lebanese thrash metal band Slave to Sirens, have a rough road ahead of them.

results.title: ‘From the Hood to the Holler’ Review: A Race to Galvanize the Poor
results.abstract: A new documentary revisits the former Kentucky state representative Charles Booker’s 2020 campaign to unseat Mitch McConnell in the Senate.

multimedia.caption: Charles Booker, a former state representative from Kentucky, in the political documentary “From the Hood to the Holler.”
Charles Booker, a former state representative from Kentucky, in the political documentary “From the Hood to the Holler.”

results.title: ‘The Justice of Bunny King’ Review: No Way Out
results.abstract: In this unsteady drama from New Zealand, Bunny, a chronic rule-bender, wants to pay a birthday visit to her daughter, but first she needs a house.

multimedia.caption: Essie Davis in “The Justice of Bunny King,” directed by Gaysorn Thavat.

results.title: ‘Vesper’ Review: Seeds of Hope
results.abstract: This elegantly visualized dystopian fantasy envelops us in the world of a gifted girl fending for survival with her sickly father.

results.title: ‘Smile’ Review: Grab and Grin
results.abstract: A young psychiatrist believes she’s being pursued by a malevolent force in this impressive horror feature debut.

results.title: ‘Blonde’ Review: Exploiting Marilyn Monroe for Old Times’ Sake
results.abstract: She was an actress of uncommon talent. But once again a director is more interested in examining her body (literally, in this case) than getting inside her mind.

multimedia.caption: In “Blonde,” Ana de Armas, right, is a fine if overwhelmed Marilyn Monroe, with Bobby Cannavale playing a character based on Joe DiMaggio, her second husband.
In “Blonde,” Ana de Armas, right, is a fine if overwhelmed Marilyn Monroe, with Bobby Cannavale playing a character based on Joe DiMaggio, her second husband.
In “Blonde,” Ana de Armas, right, is a fine if overwhelmed Marilyn Monroe, with Bobby Cannavale playing a character based on Joe DiMaggio, her second husband.

results.title: Wendell Pierce Fulfills His American Dream: Playing Willy Loman
results.abstract: A Broadway revival of “Death of a Salesman” has a Black lead for the first time, giving Pierce a chance to step into a role he was “born to play.”

multimedia.caption: “I have to know and feel that lead coat, the heaviness and the weight of the world that is placed upon Willy so that I can fight with all the fire and exuberance,” Wendell Pierce said of his approach to the role.
multimedia.copyright: Nate Palmer for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “I have to know and feel that lead coat, the heaviness and the weight of the world that is placed upon Willy so that I can fight with all the fire and exuberance,” Wendell Pierce said of his approach to the role.

results.title: Stream These 13 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in October
results.abstract: A major TV comedy and a couple of indie gems are among the many shows and movies leaving for U.S. subscribers next month. These are the ones not to miss.

results.title: Just Jaeckin, Whose ‘Emmanuelle’ Was a Scandalous Success, Dies at 82
results.abstract: His first film, the story of a young woman’s erotic adventures, was initially blocked by French censors but became a runaway hit.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker Just Jaeckin in 1975. “People see the film and leave without feeling guilty,” he said by way of explaining why his “Emmanuelle” was so popular.
The filmmaker Just Jaeckin in 1975. “People see the film and leave without feeling guilty,” he said by way of explaining why his “Emmanuelle” was so popular.
The filmmaker Just Jaeckin in 1975. “People see the film and leave without feeling guilty,” he said by way of explaining why his “Emmanuelle” was so popular.

results.title: Sundance Liked Her Documentary on Terrorism, Until Muslim Critics Didn’t
results.abstract: The film festival gave Meg Smaker’s “Jihad Rehab” a coveted spot in its 2022 lineup, but apologized after an outcry over her race and her approach.

multimedia.caption: After criticism by Arab American and Muslim filmmakers led to the film being shunned by festivals, Meg Smaker renamed her documentary “The UnRedacted.”
multimedia.copyright: Tai Power Seeff for The New York Times

results.title: Louise Fletcher, 88, Dies; Oscar Winner for ‘One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest’
results.abstract: She was largely unknown to the public when she was cast as what the American Film Institute called one of cinema’s most memorable villains.
des_facet: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (Book)

results.title: Will Anyone Give ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ a Chance?
results.abstract: Olivia Wilde’s new film is trying to fight free of its pre-release reputation.

results.title: Ryan Grantham of ‘Riverdale’ Sentenced to Life for Mother’s Murder
results.abstract: Grantham, who also appeared in the film “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” had pleaded guilty earlier this year. He will be eligible for parole after 14 years.

results.title: ‘Petrov’s Flu’ Review: Roaming a Grim, Rowdy Underworld
results.abstract: In this fever dream of a movie by Kirill Serebrennikov, a Russian man wanders a wild urban landscape that he regularly hallucinates his way out of.

multimedia.caption: Semyon Serzin in “Petrov’s Flu,” by Kirill Serebrennikov, who has been best known abroad for his difficulties with the Russian government.
